relationships.restrictions: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: GEOL452 and GEOL340.

name: Seismic Wave Propagation
description: A description of the physics of seismic wave propagation and their applications to the determination of the structure of the Earth and the mechanics of earthquakes.

relationships.prereqs: MATH140 and MATH141; and (PHYS141, PHYS161, or PHYS171); and permission of CMNS-Geology department.
relationships.restrictions: Non-degree-seeking students require the permission of the instructor.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: GEOL100 or GEOL120; and (MATH241 and MATH246); and (PHYS260 or PHYS273).

name: Geodynamics
description: The mechanics and dynamics of the Earth's interior and their applications to problems of Geophysics. This course considers several rheological descriptions of Earth materials (brittle, elastic, linear and nonlinear fluids, and viscoelastic) and emphasizes analytical solutions to simplified problem.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of CMNS-Geology department; or (MATH241, MATH462, and GEOL446).
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Familiarity with MATLAB or MATHEMATICA.

name: Cosmochemistry
description: Introduction to current theories behind the origin, age and evolution of our solar system. The primary focus will be on the interpretation of petrologic, chemical and isotopic data obtained from meteorites, and planetary materials collected by sample return missions to the Moon and asteroids. Includes in-depth discussion of the mechanisms of formation of the asteroids and planets and the origin of the Moon and Mars. Includes hands-on examination of lunar samples from the Apollo missions as well as various types of meteorites.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: GEOL650.

name: Recent Advances in Geology; Mantle Dynamics
Recent Advances in Geology; Geoscience Communication
Recent Advances in Geology; The Co-Evolution of Life and Environment from the Archean toPresent
Intensive Elementary German
description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of German-speaking world.

relationships.prereqs: Must have appropriate World Language Placement Test (WLPT) score.
relationships.restrictions: Must not be a fluent/native speaker of German.

name: Intensive Intermediate German
description: Covers speaking, reading, writing, listening, and culture of German-speaking world.

relationships.prereqs: GERS103; or must have appropriate World Language Placement Test (WLPT) score.
relationships.restrictions: Must not be a fluent/native speaker of German.

name: German Grammar Review
description: An in-depth study and analysis of selected grammatical topics in a contextualized framework.

relationships.prereqs: GERS203; or Must have appropriate World Language Placement Test (WLPT) score.
relationships.restrictions: Must not be a fluent/native speaker of German.

name: Conversation and Composition II: Current Topics in German-Speaking Society
description: Further practice in contemporary spoken and written German. Contemporary social, political, and cultural themes.

relationships.prereqs: GERS301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Practicum in Translation I
description: Problems and strategies of translation from German to English.

relationships.prereqs: GERS301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Survey of German Studies
description: Approaches to analysis of German cultural products such as literature, film, poetry, architecture and works of art. Taught in German.

relationships.prereqs: GERS301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Survey of German Studies
description: Approaches to analysis of German cultural products such as literature, film, poetry, architecture and works of art. Taught in German.

relationships.prereqs: GERS301; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Special Topics in German Studies; Reading and Transcribing German Script
description: Recommended for students who have taken at least GERS204. Focuses on developing skills for reading, deciphering, and transcribing older German scripts (Fraktur, Kurrent, Sutterlin). Project-based assign ments involve transcribing historical print documents and handwritten ma nuscripts and letters. Taught in German and English.

name: Special Topics in German Studies; Famous Classical Music Composers from German-Speaking Countries
description: Explores the lives, works, and influences of some of the most renowned classical music composers originating from German-speaking countries. From the Baroque period to the Romantic era, students will delve into the rich musical traditions of Germany, Austria, and other German-speaking regions and gain an understanding of how composers such as Johann Sebastian Bach, Ludwig van Beethoven, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, and others shaped the landscape of classical music. A highlight of this course includes attending live concerts at the Clarice Smith Performing Arts Center and the Kennedy Center. Taught in English.

name: Special Topics in German Studies; German Phonetics, Phonology, and Pronunciation
description: Recommended for students who have taken at least GERS204. Teaches students to understand and produce spoken German more easily and accurately and give future German language teachers an introduction to phonology and phonetics to help them teach listening comprehension and pronunciation confidently. No linguistics background required. Taught in German.

name: Experiential Learning
description: Internship and practicum.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of ARHU-School of Languages, Literatures, and Cultures department.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher.

name: Advanced Conversation and Composition
description: Advanced instruction in and acquisition of written and oral communication skills in German

relationships.prereqs: GERS302; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.
relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed GERS401 or GERS403.

name: Selected Topics in German Language Studies; Acquisition of German
description: Cross-listed with GERS689E.  A survey of linguistic and pedagogical research about the acquisition of German. Topics include acquisition of German as a first language (L1), as a second or other language (L2+), and the teaching of German as a foreign language. Taught in English and German.

name: Selected Topics in German Literature; Of Monsters and Men: German Romanticism
description: Critically examines the multifaceted nature of German Romanticism with a  specific focus on Gothic themes of the uncanny, irrational, sublime, and grotesque manifested in visual and literary culture. More specifically, we will attempt to answer the question of what literary monsters reveal about the human experience. Taught in German.

name: Literary or Media Genres; Early German Theater
description: Cross-listed with GERS689I.  Studies the formal and stylistic dimensions of specific genres, emphasizing genre as a social, political, and aesthetic category. Special emphasis will be placed on the emergence of a German theater in the 18th and early 19th centuries and the broader implications of class, gender, and identity on its development. Taught in German.

name: Special Topics - M.A. Level; Acquisition of German
description: Cross-listed with GERS419A.  A survey of linguistic and pedagogical research about the acquisition of German. Topics include acquisition of German as a first language (L1), as a second or other language (L2+), and the teaching of German as a foreign language. Taught in English and German.

name: Special Topics - M.A. Level; Early German Theater
description: Cross-listed with GERS689I.  Studies the formal and stylistic dimensions of specific genres, emphasizing genre as a social, political, and aesthetic category. Special emphasis will be placed on the emergence of a German theater in the 18th and early 19th centuries and the broader implications of class, gender, and identity on its development. Taught in German.

name: Special Topics - M.A. Level; Of Monsters and Men: German Romanticism
Special Topics - M.A. Level; Reading and Transcribing German Script
description: Restriction -- Must be German Studies MA student. Focuses on developing skills for reading, deciphering, and transcribing older German scripts (Fraktur, Kurrent, Sutterlin). Project-based assignments involve transcribing historical print documents and handwritten manuscripts and letters. Taught in German and English.

name: Elementary Ancient Greek II
description: Continuing development of basic grammar and reading skills; study and discussion of central aspects of Greek culture.

relationships.prereqs: GREK101; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Elementary Modern Greek II
description: It is designed for students who have already completed the first semester course (GREK111) and/or those whose level of proficiency in Greek is not advanced enough for the intermediate level. Like GREK111, an introduction is provided to the language and culture of modern Greece. Students acquire the basic tools of the language and learn to communicate in simple, everyday situations. This is the second of our two-semester sequence in Elementary Modern Greek and contributes to the fulfillment of the Global Engagement requirement of the College of Arts and Humanities.

relationships.prereqs: GREK111; or permission of instructor.

name: Intermediate Modern Greek II
description: A continuation in the development of fluency in spoken and written communication along with the exploration of syntactic and grammatical structures. Comprehension and vocabulary enrichment are further developed through selected readings from Modern Greek prose and poetry. This is the second of our two-semester sequence in Intermediate Modern Greek and contributes to the fulfillment of the Global Engagement requirement of the College of Arts and Humanities.

relationships.prereqs: GREK211; or permission of instructor.

name: Scenes from Athenian Life
description: Makes the transition from study of Greek grammar to reading. Focus on selected aspects of life in Athens: marriage, friendship, the courts, festival, theatre. Reading short works by three authors: Lysias, Plato, and a playwright (e.g., Menander). Readings are in ancient Greek.

name: Topics in Advanced Modern Greek Language and Culture; Advanced Modern Greek II
Modern Greek Literature and History
description: Students will study historical and political events in Greece during the 19th and 20th centuries through the viewpoint of the man of letters.  Poetry, prose, plays, and essays reflect national emancipation, social reconstruction, and political struggles. Readings and discussion are in Modern Greek.

relationships.prereqs: Students must have earned a grade of C- or better in a 300-level Modern Greek course.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of instructor.

name: Independent Study in Greek Language and Literature
Special Topics in Greek Literature; Tragedy and Comedy
American Government
description: A comprehensive study of national government in the United States.

name: International Political Relations
description: A study of the major factors underlying international relations, the causes of conflict and cooperation among international actors, the role of international institutions, the interactions of domestic and foreign policies, and major issues in security, economy and the environment.

name: Scope and Methods for Political Science Research
description: An introduction to empirical research in political science.

name: The Challenge of Authoritarianism
description: An introduction to the persistent challenge of authoritarianism. The course explores the nature of authoritarianism and its evolution from ancient through modern times. Students will study how authoritarian regimes vary, why citizens sometimes comply with them, and when and how citizens rebel. The course concludes with a review of contemporary authoritarianism, focusing on its resilience in the Middle East and East Asia and its potential for a resurgence in the US and Europe.

name: Uncertain Partners: US and China in a Changing World
description: The rapid ascent of the People's Republic of China (PRC) as a major political and economic power has meant that its relationship with the United States has become central in contemporary international politics.  To an increasing extent, some of the biggest global challenges--ranging from nuclear proliferation, to climate change, to economic growth--require U.S.-China cooperation if they are to be managed effectively. Yet the U.S.-China relationship is at times turbulent, and its future remains highly uncertain. Will the U.S. and China be able to forge a closer partnership that will enable them to cooperate in dealing with some of the vexing challenges facing the international community?  Or are they more likely to drift toward a more adversarial relationship, as China's growing power--and the US reaction--generate a vicious cycle of mutual mistrust?  In this class, students will grapple with these questions as they learn about the history of U.S.-China relations, and about many of the current issues facing the relationship.

name: Introduction to Formal Theories of Political Behavior and Politics
description: An introduction to the theories of rational choice including theories of negotiation and bargaining, elections and voting in democracies, community organizing and the contrast between the roles and performances of government and market.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170.

name: The Study of Political Philosophy: Ancient and Modern
description: Examines some of the salient continuities and breaks between the ancient and modern traditions in Western political philosophy.

name: Introduction to Environmental Politics
description: An overview of modern environmental philosophy, politics, and policy, exploring environmental politics in the US by way of comparison with other developed and developing countries.

name: The Politics of Global Development
description: A study of the domestic governmental institutions; processes and problems such as conflict and economic development; and the socio-economic environments that are common to lower-income countries around the world.

relationships.additional_info: This is a GVPT Global Learning offering.  For more information click here.

name: Global Environmental Politics
description: Focus on three processes of international environmental policy development- identifying problems, negotiating solutions, and implementing agreements- through a range of case studies, including global climate change.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Government & Politics; Government & Politics: International Relations) ; or permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department.
relationships.additional_info: Open to students in the ENSP: Environmental Politics & Policy program.

name: Mock Trial II: Advanced Trial Advocacy
description: Development of trial advocacy skills through participation in practice trials and intercollegiate mock trial competitions. Student may have an opportunity to represent the university in intercollegiate mock trial tournaments, including the National Mock Trial Championships.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT217.

name: Classroom to Careers; Classroom to Careers
description: Embarking on a career post-college is both an exhilarating and a challenging journey. This course is designed to demystify the transitionfrom university to professional life for GVPT students. Participants will engage in a structured process to identify their professional interests and navigate through potential career avenues. Weekly sessions will feature in-person meetings with GVPT alumni from diverse sectors, offering students a unique opportunity to gain insightsfrom several real-world professional trajectories. By the course's conclusion, students will notonly have a framework for career planning but also firsthand narratives that bridge the gap between academic study and professional endeavor.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Advanced Empirical Research
description: Allows students to build on the knowledge of statistical inference they gained from GVPT201. Topics include data collection, data cleaning, data analysis, and data visualization. By the time students complete this class, they will be able to do basic statistical modeling using OLS regression independently.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT201.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics or Government & Politics: International Relations program.
relationships.additional_info: Students will be required to download statistical package R onto their own laptops and must bring their laptop to every class meeting beginning on February 7.

name: Courts, Law and Justice
description: An introductory course to the study of law with emphasis on how lawyers and judges think and argue. Topics include, contract law, property, family law, torts, and criminal procedure.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170.
relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with MLAW358W.

name: Capstone in International Conflict Management
description: Serves as one of the two capstone courses for the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management. Focuses on advanced theory and the practice and profession of international conflict management and is designed to provide students an introduction to, and a chance to engage with, a core set of practical skills relevant to the field.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT354.
relationships.restrictions: Enrollment is restricted to students in the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management; and sophomore standing or higher; and permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department.

name: Capstone in International Development
description: Serves as one of the two capstone courses for the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management. Focuses on advanced theory and the practice and profession of international development and is designed to provide students an introduction to, and a chance to engage with, a core set of practical skills relevant to the field.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT354.
relationships.restrictions: Enrollment is restricted to students in the Minor in International Development and Conflict Management; and sophomore standing or higher; and permission of BSOS-Government & Politics department.
relationships.additional_info: A Fearless Ideas Course from the Academy for Innovation & Entrepreneurship (AIE): http://ter.ps/iamFEARLESS  Click here for more information on the Fearless Ideas Courses.

name: Special Topics in Government and Politics; U.S Foreign Policy and the Arab-Israeli Conflict
description: Cross-listed with ISRL349F.  What are the U.S.' interests in the Middle East? Who and what defines these interests, or how to pursue them diplomatically and militarily? The Arab/Palestinian-Israeli conflict is a defining feature of the modern Middle East and it unquestionably has a significant impact on U.S. domestic politics and international leadership. Given those realities, this course will examine how U.S. foreign and security affecting the Arab/Palestinian-Israeli conflict is made and how it shapes and determines the realities on the ground, as well as the prospects for its peaceful resolution.

name: Asian American Politics
description: Students will gain a greater understanding of 1) the role of Asian Americans in US politics, 2) the political attitudes and behaviors of Asian Americans and 3) how to conduct research on Asian American politics. Though the class will concentrate on Asian Americans, issues related to Asian American politics will be examined within the larger context of America's multicultural political landscape.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: AAST443, AMST498J.

name: Special Topics in Government and Politics; The Arabs in Israel: Palestinian Arab Citizens of Israel
description: Cross-listed with ISRL349N.  This course examines the political, social, and economic experience of the Arab minority in Israel from the establishment of the State up until recent years. It addresses the relationship between the State and the Arab community and the distinctive internal dynamics of Arab society as well as the relationship between the Arab minority in Israel and the Palestinians, and the Arab world.

name: Special Topics in Government and Politics; Advanced Field Research in African American Politics
description: Cross-listed with AASP479A.  This course is designed to guide students through the process of conducting advanced research on political and societal phenomena that impact the Black community. Students will receive hands-on experience conducting field experiments, deploying in-person and virtual surveys, conducting interviews and focus groups, and analyzing data.

name: Special Topics in Government and Politics; Israel, Middle East Security, and WMD Proliferation
description: Cross-listed with IRSL349T.   This course addresses one of Israel's main security concerns:the spread  of nuclear, chemical, and biological weapons in the Middle East. It  analyzes in-depth the political dynamics that lead to proliferation  dangers in the region and the possible Israeli responses to  proliferation, such as deterrence, military strikes, prevention,  preemption, and defense.

name: Experiential Learning: Government and Politics Internship Program
description: The application of major concepts of political science to the realities of the political process. The course connects internship experiences with larger themes of political science. Students must be admitted to the GVPT Internship Program.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170.
relationships.additional_info:
Students interested in registering for this course must have an internship secured and must apply to the GVPT Internship Program. Required in-person class meetings will take place 6:30pm-9:15pm on the following Wednesdays: February 21, March 27, and April 24.
													
												
													
														 Click here for more course information.

name: Topical Investigations
description: Permission of Director of Undergraduate Studies required.

name: Topical Investigations; Global Environmental Justice
description: This is a GVPT Global Learning offering. The course will meet on campus during the spring semester and complete a trip to Montreal over the 2025 Spring Break. Students must complete both GVPT388G and the Spring Break study abroad course GVPT388N. This course will examine the relationship between environmental problems and social justice through global lens; we will explore different approaches to environmental justice, and examine why and how some groups are impacted unequally by environmental hazards, and how we might pursue a more just outcome.

name: Topical Investigations; Mock Trial Independent Study

relationships.prereqs: Permission of department.

name: Game Theory
description: Introduction to game theory with applications to political science, economics and sociology. Topics include preference theory, expected utility theory, Nash equilibria, subgame perfection, repeated games, folk theorems, and evolutionary stability.

relationships.restrictions: Must not have completed ECON414.

name: Introduction to Honors Research
description: A required course for all honors students designed to emphasize library research, methodology, and writing skills in political science and political philosophy. A written proposal, bibliography and research design for an honors paper required of all students as a final project.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics Honors Program; and must have permission of the Government & Politics Honors Program.

name: Honors Research
description: Individual reading and research. Preparation of an original paper.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT396.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics Honors Program.

name: Political Economy of Foreign Aid
description: The world spends hundreds of billions of dollars on foreign aid every year. The effects of this aid spending are controversial. Research supports both pessimistic and optimistic views of foreign aid's effectiveness, with little consensus. Where does aid money go? What are the motivations of aid donors? Is foreign aid effective at achieving its goals? Why or why not? This course is designed to survey the promise and the challenges of foreign aid as a policy tool. The first half of the course will focus on the motivations and goals of foreign aid. We will consider various foreign aid donors, such as countries, institutions, and individuals, to understand the motivations behind and effects of foreign aid. We will create a typology of foreign aid agendas, motivations, and donors. The second half of the course will consider the challenges specific to foreign aid. This includes both technical challenges and political challenges. We will consider the strategies that aid donors and organizations have taken to try to overcome these challenges.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics or Government & Politics: International Relations program.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: GVPT200.

name: International Organizations
description: A basic introduction to the full range of international organizations that have come into being over the past century and one-half, including those that aspire to be universal or global, those with a geopolitical or regional focus, and those that address specific structural or functional areas of human endeavor or issue areas.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program; and junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program; and junior standing or higher.

name: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; Corporations and the Global Political Economy
description: The course will examine corporations as political actors in global politics, analyzing power, norms and governance in different issue areas.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; International Relations of the Middle East
description: This seminar will evaluate major issues of the international relations of the Middle East and the American role and responses to these issues. The seminar will focus on several post-Cold War cases in American foreign policy, including the 1991 and 2003 Gulf wars, policy toward Iran, American mediation in the Arab-Israeli conflict, responses to the Arab Uprisings, re-emerging competition with Russia, and broader issues such as regional reform and nuclear non-proliferation.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics Honors program.

name: Seminar in International Relations and World Politics; Southeast Asia in Contemporary Global Politics
description: Southeast Asia, home to three major religious cultures and various regime types, is one of the most politically and socially diverse regions of the world. While the region is unique for its diversity, its states face challenges that are common in other parts of the world including globalization; adjusting to the new geopolitical landscape of rising global powers; and external pressure to improve the standards of human rights, the environment and democracy. Given this dynamic political context, this course is designed to give students a greater understanding of the problems and prospects of the region, as well as the ability to assess its efforts to adapt to the changing regional and international environment.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program or Government & Politics: International Relations program.

name: Seminar in Advanced Topics in Environmental Policy Analysis
description: A series of critical tools and methods used to analyze environmental policy. This class should be of interest to students who are either considering a career or graduate studies in environmental protection.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT273.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Government & Politics; Environmental Sci&Policy-Env Politics & Policy).

name: Seminar in Public Policy; Applied Policy Research
description: Recommended prerequisite: GVPT320  In this course students will learn how to apply theories of public policy and evaluate policy effectiveness. Students will examine several policy areas and consider the challenges faced both in implementation and in attempts to evaluate policy outcomes. Students will collect and analyze data related to a policy area of their choice and derive assessments and recommendations from the data. By the end of the course students will have a better understanding of the policy implementation process and of the skills necessary to find evidence for whether or not policy is successful.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT201.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Problems in Political Behavior; Digital Dictatorships
description: This course explores the digital strategies used by dictatorialregimes as well as the digital data and methodology scholars use to understand autocratic politics. Students will pursue a semester-long project of their choosing.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT201.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government and Politics program.

name: Problems in Political Behavior; Social Media Politics
description: This seminar presents students with an integrated view of media politics, combining political psychology, computational social science, and network analysis. The goal is to provide students with the technical know-how to work with social media data and the knowledge to interpret relevant information. In this seminar, students will learn to process social media data, program survey experiments, and identify political narratives in a multiplatform environment. The seminar will introduce students to the computational techniques required for big social media data analyses.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT201.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Civil Rights and the Constitution
description: A study of civil rights in the American constitutional context, emphasizing freedom of religion, freedom of expression, minority discrimination, and the rights of defendants.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170 and GVPT331.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Government & Politics; Government & Politics: International Relations).
relationships.additional_info: Credit only graned for GVPT432 or MLAW358Y.

name: Seminar in Public Law; Introduction to Moot Court
description: Recommended Prerequisites: GVPT431, GVPT432, and GVPT439B. Not open to students who have completed GVPT439M Moot Court. This is an introductory class in appellate advocacy. It will teach you the skills and methods necessary to compete in regional and national Moot Court competitions. In moot courting, students assume the role of advocates in a hypothetical Supreme Court case. You will learn how to identify relevant case law, how to structure an oral argument and how to develop a written brief in the hypothetical case. The semester will conclude with each student arguing the case for his or her "client" before a panel of practicing lawyers and jurists. No prior experience in oral advocacy is necessary. Students must commit to a virtual moot court practice which will take place in the evening. Contact the instructor for more information.

name: Seminar in Political Philosophy; Social Philosophy and Political Economy
description: This course examines capitalism and socialism as differing modes of economic production through several different theoretical lenses. We begin by examining capitalism and socialism as they developed historically, by looking primarily at the work of Adam Smith and Karl Marx. Then, we turn our attention to one of the most important debates 20th century economics: to what extent rational economic calculation is possible in a socialist commonwealth. After this we turn our attention to how capitalist and socialist modes of production functioned in practice. We end by turning our attention to the ethics of capitalism and socialism: which mode of economic production is most just?

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program or Government & Politics: International Relations program.

name: Seminar in Political Philosophy; Global Justice
description: The course begins by laying the foundation for the debate over the scope and limits of global justice, and then examines some topics that arise when thinking globally about justice, such as poverty, the environment and waging war. The course ends by considering the possibility of creating a cosmopolitan framework within which to adjudicate between competing interests in the globalized world.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program; or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program.

name: Seminar in the International Relations of China
description: Explores the foreign relations behavior of the People's Republic of China, with focus on the contemporary era.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program; and junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: Or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program; and junior standing or higher.

name: American Foreign Relations
description: The principles and machinery of the conduct of American foreign relations and an analysis of the major foreign policies of the United States.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program; and junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: This is a GVPT Global Learning offering.  For more information click here.

name: Seminar in Comparative Politics; Politics of India
Seminar in Comparative Politics; Dictators and Dictatorships: Comparative Perspectives
Seminar in Comparative Politics; Race and Ethnic Politics in Comparative Perspective
description: Not open to students who have completed GVPT459C.  This course examines the multiple ways in which race and ethnicity  become meaningful categories shaping political behavior. We will  examine how race and ethnicity are socially constructed, why people  accept (and sometimes reject) the categories imposed on them, and how  categories and identities become drivers of political behavior. The  course takes a comparative perspective on identity politics, looking at  cases from multiple regions around the world.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics Honors Program.

name: Seminar in Comparative Politics; Regime Types: Democracies and Nondemocracies
description: Recommended Prerequisites: GVPT200 and GVPT280  Not open to students who have completed:GVPT359J. This course will address four main themes: 1) regime change from a democracy to an autocracy; 2) regime change from an autocracy to a democracy; 3) democracies becoming less democratic; and 4) autocracies becoming less autocratic.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Seminar in Comparative Politics; Russian Politics: From Lenin to Putin

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Goverment & Politics program.

name: The U.S. Congress
description: A detailed survey of lawmaking and the legislative process, emphasizing the U.S. Congress, and its members.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT241 and GVPT170.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher.
relationships.additional_info: And must be in Government & Politics program; or must be in Government & Politics: International Relations program.

name: The Presidency and the Executive Branch
description: An examination of the U.S. presidency in historical and contemporary perspective: nomination and electoral politics and the president's place in policy-making, administration, and public opinion.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT241 and GVPT170.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program; and junior standing or higher.

name: Seminar in American Politics; Interest Groups and Social Movements
description: This course focuses on interest groups and social movements as important forces in American politics that provide ways for citizens to affect public policy.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Seminar in American Politics; Historical and Demographic Shifts in the U.S. Congress
description: This course will examine specific events and activities that have sparked major shifts in the organizational structure, composition, and productivity of the U.S. Congress. In so doing, the course will explore the relationship that the legislative branch has with its partnering governmental branches and agencies while examining various internal organizational changes. This course will survey congressional shifts while also providing tools to better understand the traditional framework of the U.S. Congress.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170 Restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Seminar in American Politics; Power, Representation, and Public Policy
description: Many classes focus on a narrow aspect of the American political system such as Congress, courts, or voter behavior. All of these are important topics, but for many their importance lies in their connection to broader processes of representation and policy-making. In this class we will survey many topics as they bear upon these two broader themes: who makes policy and who is represented? Readings include both classics and recent studies reflecting differing approaches to scholarship.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170 Restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Seminar in American Politics; Hidden Figures: Women of Color in Politics
description: This course explores the significant role that women of color have played in American politics. Using an intersectional lens, we critically engage biographical, autobiographical, and historical works that give voice to the political experiences of individual women of color. We broaden the notion of "politics" to be inclusive of women of color that are close confidants of male political figures (first ladies, wives, and "mistresses"), revolutionaries, activists, as well as those that serve in formal political positions (elected officials, politicians, and justices). Finally, we grapple with the impact of public policy on the lives of women of color.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT170 Restriction: Must be in Government & Politics program.

name: Government and Politics of Africa
description: A comparative study of the governmental systems and political processes of the African countries, with special emphasis on the problems of nation-building in emergent countries.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT282 or GVPT280.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in one of the following programs (Government & Politics; Government & Politics: International Relations).

name: Introduction to Conflict and Cooperation in the World Economy
description: This seminar examines major theoretical approaches and empirical studies of international political economy, contemporary dynamics of globalization, the role of domestic politics in the formation of foreign economic policies of states, the dynamics of international trade and investment disputes, and role of international institutions in multi-lateral governance of the world economy. The focus is on developing an understanding of central debates in the literature and primary empirical findings from quantitative and cross-national analyses that are of policy relevance.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT604.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in the International Relations Master's program; or permission of Government and Politics department.

name: Introduction to International Institutions and International Law
description: This seminar examines major theoretical approaches and empirical studies of international law and institutions relating to international political economy and international security. Topics to be covered include the sources of international law and the development of core legal principles in the post-WWII ear, the role of international economic institutions such as WTO, IMF, and World Bank in the global economy, and the influence of international institutions such as the UN Security Council, World Court, and International Criminal Court in addressing international security issues. Larger questions about the effectiveness of the WTO, Laws of War, and International Human Rights Law will be considered. The focus is on developing an understanding of central debates in the literature and primary empirical findings from quantitative and cross-national analyses that are of policy relevance.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT604.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in the International Relations Master's program; or permission of Government and Politics department.

name: National Security and International Relations
description: Introduction to key areas of research in national security and international relations. Students will learn the major approaches to empirical research on national and international security and work with datasets focused on terrorist attacks and civil conflict.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Applied Political Analytics Master of Science program; or permission of department.

name: Voting, Campaigns, and Elections
description: Introduction to the theoretical and empirical research on political participation, campaigns, and elections.  By gaining an understanding of the literature and working with a variety of data sets, including surveys and voter history files, students will be equipped to carry out their own research on these topics.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Applied Political Analytics Master of Science program; or permission of department.

name: Applied Evaluation and Analysis of Government Policy
description: The public policy approach at both state and federal levels; policy considerations and restrictions; methods of testing and evaluation; collecting and cleaning policy data.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Applied Political Analytics (APAN); or permission of department.

name: Advanced Quantitative Methods For Political Science
description: Introduction to multivariate analysis. Elementary matrix algebra, multiple linear and curvilinear correlation and regression, analysis of variance, canonical correlation and regression, discriminant analysis, and several types of factor analysis.

relationships.prereqs: GVPT622; or permission of instructor.

name: Special Topics in Quantitative Political Analysis; Causal Inference
Special Topics in Quantitative Political Analysis; Text-as-Data
Special Topics in Quantitative Political Analysis; Quantitative Analyses of International Political Economy and International Security
International Political Economy
description: Major issues in international political economy including such matters as the monetary system, trade, debt, and development.

relationships.additional_info: Recommended: GVPT708.

name: Seminar in American Political Behavior
description: This is the core seminar in American political behavior. The course will deal with prominent theoretical and empirical issues in the areas of voting, public opinion, political participation and other aspects of political behavior in the American context.

name: Selected Topics in Functional Problems in International Relations; Conflict and World Politics
Selected Topics in Functional Problems in International Relations; Prospectus Seminar

Topics on International Security; Research Design and Analysis in International Relations

Selected Topics in Comparative Governmental Institutions; Politics of Identity
Applied Cybersecurity Foundations
description: Prepares students for team research that will be conducted in HACS 200. Students gain an understanding across the breadth of cybersecurity including system monitoring, networking basics and penetration testing. An applied approach to statistics is also included to prepare students to assess the data collected for their research projects. The course is conducted with a hands-on approach applying virtual environments to practice the concepts learned in the technical lectures each week.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HACS100.
relationships.restrictions: Must be a second-semester student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.

name: Introduction to UNIX
description: Introduction to the operating system UNIX through lectures and hands-on assignments.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a first-year student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.
relationships.additional_info: Required course for students who have not completed the ACES Living-Learning Program or taken CMSC216.

name: Group Project in Cybersecurity
description: The group project in this course will combine technical, analytical, and communication skills, further engaging students in the practice of cybersecurity. Students will learn about design concepts and data analysis as they engage in a team project designing, deploying, and collecting and analyzing data from a honeypot. The hands-on nature of the course will give students experiential insight about how and why attackers attack and how to engage in protective measures to prevent attacks.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a first-year student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program; and cannot have been an ACES Living-Learning Program student (i.
relationships.additional_info: e., have taken HACS100, HACS101 and HACS200).Restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.

name: Introduction to Reverse Engineering
description: An introduction to software reverse engineering tools and methodologies. Fundamental topics will be introduced: compilers, linkers, loaders, assembly language, as well as static and dynamic analysis tools. We will motivate some reasons for software reverse engineering and examine the background material necessary for an understanding of the subject. This will include computer architecture and low-level systems programming, as well as an introduction to x86_64 assembly language. We will apply this newly acquired knowledge while learning about static and dynamic analysis tools used by practitioners of software reverse engineering.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.

name: Security Incident Handling and Management
description: Examines the many roles, capabilities, organizations, and objectives involved in security incident handling and management. Core course content includes three major components: learning about the skill sets that people use, participating in role playing exercises that increasingly build upon this knowledge, and finally conducting exercises in a lab environment simulating security incident discovery, handling, and management.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.
relationships.additional_info: Repeatable to 6 credits if content differs.

name: Beyond Technology, the Policy Implications of Cyberspace
description: Explores the key issues facing policy makers attempting to manage the problem of cybersecurity from its technical foundations to the domestic and international policy considerations surrounding governance, response, and critical infrastructure risk management. The course is designed for students with little to no background in information technology, and will provide the principles to understand the current debates shaping a rapidly evolving security landscape.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.
relationships.additional_info: Restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.

name: Methods for Solving (And not Solving) Puzzles
description: Surveys modern problems from different domains in computer science and cybersecurity to train our minds to appropriately approach puzzles we encounter in the future. This course covers graph theory, including what a graph is and the kinds of objects it can model, connectivity types, and vertex/edge covers algorithms. This course covers computer networks, including the models used for network stacks and what algorithms are used to solve difficult problems present in our current networks. This course covers algorithm analysis, including greedy algorithms, big O complexity, and how to analyze the capabilities and limitations of an algorithm. This course introduces cryptography, including the difference between public-key and symmetric-key cryptography, how RSA works, and the cryptanalysis of well-known cryptosystems.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program.
relationships.additional_info: Restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program

name: Undergraduate Research in Cybersecurity
description: The Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students (ACES) program encourages its students to engage in research in order to gain greater insight into a specific area within cybersecurity, obtain an appreciation for the subtleties and difficulties associated with the production of knowledge and fundamental new applications, and to prepare for graduate school and the workforce.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program; and permission of UGST-HCOL-ACES Cybersecurity Program.

name: Cybersecurity Experience Reflection
description: Cybersecurity experience is defined as an experiential learning activity either with a University of Maryland entity (such as the Division of Information Technology, the ACES competition team or in an ACES outreach program), or with an external organization that will provide valuable, hands-on experience to supplement the knowledge learned in the other ACES coursework.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Living-Learning Program; and permission of UGST-HCOL-ACES Cybersecurity Program.

description: Restriction: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program

name: Interpersonal Cyber Communications
description: Designed to prepare students to participate in culturally responsible and environmentally appropriate communication in the workforce. Students will explore the industry standards for writing technical reports, as well as the variances between persuasive, team, written, and oral communication styles.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.
relationships.additional_info: Repeatable to 6 credits if content differs.

name: Advanced Seminar in Cybersecurity; Project Management for IT Professionals

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.

name: Penetration Testing
description: A hands-on, technically rigorous experience that prepares students for real-world work in penetration testing and offensive security. This course will allow students to gain proficiency and become comfortable using the tools, techniques, and methodologies that represent the state of the art in penetration testing today. Students should be comfortable on the command line, and a technical exposure to networking and basic proficiency in some scripting language (Bash, Ruby, or Python) is expected.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.
relationships.additional_info: Repeatable to 6 credits if content differs.

name: Data Analysis and Visualization for Cybersecurity
description: Focuses on exploratory and statistical data analysis, data and information visualization, and the presentation and communication of analysis results. These topics will be presented and explored in the context of and with applications to cyber security related data. Examples and illustrations will often involve the R programming language, but prior experience with R is not required and submitted work may involve the use of other languages and tools at times.

relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program.
relationships.additional_info: Repeatable to 6 credits if content differs.

name: Cybersecurity Experience Reflection
description: Cybersecurity experience is defined as an experiential learning activity either with a University of Maryland entity or with an external organization that will provide valuable, hands-on experience to supplement the knowledge learned in other ACES coursework. This course is intended to help students reflect on their cybersecurity experience and to learn from others' cybersecurity experiences. It is also intended to help students gain professional skills that will aid in their future career.

relationships.prereqs: Students may enroll concurrently with or after completing a cybersecurity related internship experience of at least 135 hours.
relationships.restrictions: Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program; and must not have taken HACS297.
Must be a student in the ACES (Advanced Cybersecurity Experience for Students) Minor Program; and permission of UGST-HCOL- ACES Cybersecurity Program.

name: The Future of Analysis: Making Data Driven Decisions in Business
description: Students will address questions regarding how business is being shaped by the increased use of data.  The course draws from various quantitative, computation, and technical fields to develop a big picture understanding of data science in business.  Through examples and applications, students will address the challenging questions related to artificial intelligence, data science bias, and privacy.

relationships.prereqs: HBUS100.

name: Capstone in Interdisciplinary Business
description: As the capstone course in the Interdisciplinary Business Honors (IBH) Program, this course will give students the opportunity to apply what they have learned in the IBH program to a real-world company.  This company will help present students with an opportunity to address a pressing challenge

relationships.prereqs: HBUS100, HBUS105, and HBUS200.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Interdisciplinary Business Honors Program.

name: Seminar in Design Cultures & Creativity
description: Introduction to the methods and theory of design production, with emphasis on creative and expressive platforms.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in the Design Cultures and Creativity Honors College Living/Learning program.

Capstone in Design Cultures and Creativity

Intensive Elementary Hebrew II
description: A continuation of intensive study of fundamentals of Hebrew reading, writing, listening, speaking and Israeli culture. Covers past tense in all verb categories, basic syntax and builds vocabulary.

name: Intensive Intermediate Hebrew II
description: A review of the fundamentals of Hebrew grammar, reading, writing, listening and speaking.

relationships.prereqs: Must have completed HEBR206 OR HEBR211; or have the appropriate Score on the World Language Placement Test; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Special Topics in Hebrew Studies; Israeli Entrepreneurship
description: Students examine startups, technology and ideas that started in Israel and were exported internationally. After exposure to media clips, articles, interviews, business plans, podcasts and advertising, students will create their own startup elevator pitch and business idea.

name: Conversation and Composition II
description: A practical language course recommended for all students continuing with Hebrew. Review of grammar and composition. Selected readings. Oral and written exercises.

relationships.prereqs: HEBR313; or students who have taken courses with comparable content may contact the department.

name: Experiential Learning
description: Restriction: Must have a Learning Proposal approved by the Office of Experiential Learning Programs, faculty sponsor, and student's internship sponsor; and junior standing or higher.

relationships.additional_info: Contact the department to obtain section numbers.

name: Special Topics in Hebrew Studies
description: Cross-listed with JWST319W and ISRL349W.  Examination of the history, linguistics, politics and sociology of Modern Israeli Hebrew slang, including influences from popular American culture, technology, the military, Arabic and immigrant group languages. Taught in English; course materials in Hebrew with translation.

name: Independent Study in Hebrew
description: Contact the department to obtain section numbers.

name: Special Problems in Higher Education, Student Affairs, and International Education Policy; Student Entertainment Events, Executive Director Training and Onboarding
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy

name: Transfer2Terp Learning Community: Applying Your Strengths at the University of Maryland and Beyond
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Students will identify their strengths and learn how to apply them both in and outside of the classroom. Students will work side by side with the faculty and staff in the Adele H. Stamp Student Union to learn about their strengths while applying them to leadership positions.

relationships.restrictions: Priority will be given to students transferring from Maryland Community Colleges; or permission of EDUC-Counseling, Higher Education and Special Education department.

name: Applied Contextual Leadership; Greek Presidents Class
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Course restricted to Fraternity and Sorority Presidents. For permission, please contact Tyler Huddleston at thuddles@umd.edu

name: Applied Contextual Leadership; Peer Facilitation in the Fraternity and Sorority Community
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Social norms are co-created by peers within a community and addressing cultural issues like power-based violence requires community trust, engagement, and commitment to change. Learners will engage with readingsto develop a broad understanding of sexual assault on college campuses and within the Fraternity and Sorority community as well as theories of leadership and communication that provide context to be ableto effectively facilitate group conversations by cultivating trust, creativity, and engagement.

name: Applied Contextual Leadership; Orientation Leader
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: students hired to be on the Orientation staff

name: Applied Contextual Leadership; Foundations and Applications of Adventure Leadership Instruction
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Permission of Instructor needed. Required course to become an Adventure Trip Leader with the RecWell Adventure Program. Contact Meghan Loughry at mloughry@umd.edu to schedule an interview.

name: Special Topics in Leadership; Global Leadership in a Virtual Context
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: This is a Global Classrooms course developed in partnership with the Office of International Affairs (OIA) to provide opportunities for virtual, project based, international collaboration. Learn more about Global Classrooms: go.umd.edu/gci. In this course, UMD students explore cross-cultural leadership and global issues while engaging on virtual teams with students from an international institution to complete a collaborative project. Students are required to join 5-7 live online class sessions onselect evenings to accommodate time zone differences with our international partners. All other coursework is asynchronous. Contact leadershipstudies@umd.edu for more information.

name: Leadership and the Black Community
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Examines leadership from the perspective of the African American experience. Specifically, we will explore the concept and differing meanings of "leader and leadership" within the African-American community in the United States. Issues of leaders and leadership will be examined as influenced by political, cultural, and historic events. The course will place particular emphasis on colleges and universities as a microcosm of the larger society and as a cultural site for exploring and assessing issues of African American leadership.

name: Women and Leadership
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: The primary goal of this course is for students to develop an understanding of women's leadership and women's ways of influencing organizations. The course will rely heavily on the idea that you must know yourself first before you explore how "you" fit into the organization and how that organization fits into a broader context such as nation, culture, or community. We will talk about the social constructs of leadership and gender, including systems and structures, and the role media, television, movies, and sports play in defining women and their leadership in a cultural context. The exploration of women leaders will be broad based including the role that gender identity and expression, race, sexual orientation, country of origin, and ethnicity/culture play in women's definition and the expression of their leadership.

name: Leadership and the Jewish Community
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Offers students the opportunity to critically examine leadership and leadership identity development in relation to Jewish culture and identity. Explores how Jewish culture and ethnicity influence leadership styles and the role that leadership has played within Jewish history. Students will explore general leadership theories as well as personal leadership identity development in both an overall sense and as a member of the Jewish community. Examines leaders within the Jewish movement and how their leadership has influenced Jewish communities and explores issues facing the Jewish community both on college campuses and in the world and prepare student leaders to act as advocates for the Jewish community.

name: Field Experiences in Higher Education, Student Affairs, and International Education Policy
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy

name: Organizational Dimensions of Student Affairs
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Exploration of leadership and organizational change of student affairs programs in post-secondary education.

relationships.prereqs: EDCP610; or permission of EDUC-Counseling, Higher Education and Special Education department.

name: Women and Gender in Higher Education
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: This course is a seminar on women in higher education. From the history of women accessing higher education to the current topics and issues that shape the lived realities of students, faculty, and student development educators, this course will examine experiences of women in the U.S. system of higher education. By applying a theoretical understanding and analyzing the intersections of women's multiple identities, we will develop skills and strategies to further support and empower women. This course is designed to facilitate open, systematic and scholarly exploration of women within the broad and diverse area of higher education. You will be challenged to examine and to personally reflect on the basic "Who, What, Why, and Where" questions that, when taken together, provide a comprehensive portrait of women in higher education.

name: The College Student
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: A demographic study of the characteristics of college students as well as a study of their aspirations, values, and purposes.

relationships.additional_info: This is a Global Classrooms course, developed in partnership with the Office of International Affairs (OIA) to provide opportunities for virtual, project-based, international collaboration. Learn more about Global Classrooms: go.umd.edu/gci.

name: Designing Qualitative Research in Counseling and Student Affairs Contexts
department: Higher Ed, Student Affairs, and International Ed Policy
description: Introduction to philosophical and epistemological foundations, methodologies and methods associated with qualitative research designs appropriate in student affairs and counseling contexts.

name: Introduction to Linguistics
description: An introduction to the scientific study of natural language with focus on the basic concepts of phonology, syntax, semantics and pragmatics, with subsequent attention to the applied aspects of linguistic principles.

relationships.additional_info: HESP120 is required for HESP majors.  HESP majors may not substitute LING200.

name: Introduction to Language Science
description: Language science is the scientific study of how humans acquire, use, comprehend, and produce language.  Most people in all societies learn and use their native language or languages with apparent ease - but don't be fooled: languages are highly complex, and speaking and understanding language requires some amazing feats of mental acrobatics. Thus there are many opportunities for difficulties with language, which is the focus of our field. Understanding difficulties with speech, language, and hearing require first understanding how processing works when language is successful - the psychological (behavioral) and neurobiological (brain) factors that enable people to learn and use language despite its intricacies, the structure and properties of language itself, and how knowledge of language is acquired, represented, and processed in the mind and brain.

name: Introduction to Hearing and Speech Sciences
description: An introduction to communication sciences and disorders; a survey of the bases of normal speech, language and hearing ability, major forms of communicative disorders and their treatment.

name: The Research Behind Headlines on Words, Thought, and Behavior
description: How does the human mind use language? Type "Language Science News" into your Google search bar. Among the more than 3 billion hits, headlines like "What is love? It depends what language you speak" and "Science's English dominance hinders diversity" invite you to think about the impact of words on thought and behavior. These are stories about how humans acquire and use language, but they ultimately address big questions about how we experience knowledge itself. In a world of unprecedented access to science journalism, did you ever read a headline about human behavior and wonder: How do we know? This class takes up the elegant ways cognitive scientists design experiments to answer crucial questions about language and thought, brain and behavior, that have no intuitive answers. Students will dive deep into the media coverage of their favorite claims about what we know, debate the psychological science behind these claims, and develop transferable critical-thinking skills in the process.

relationships.additional_info: Cross-listed with: HNUH278A.

name: Introduction to Psycholinguistics
description: An introduction to current theories of language and an investigation of their relationship to human communication behavior. Survey of the experimental literature relating to this question.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP202; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: HESP120.

name: Phonetic transcription
description: An introduction to broad and narrow phonetic transcription, and to physiology of speech production. The primary goal of the course is to provide knowledge about phonetics and the ability to use this knowledge in an applied setting.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of instructor.

name: Anatomy and Physiology of Speech & Hearing
description: This is a 4-credit course focusing on the biological and neurological bases of human speech production and human hearing, namely the anatomy, physiology, and neurology of the vocal/speech mechanism and the hearing mechanism.Specifically, respiration, phonation, resonance, articulation, swallowing, and hearing will be highlighted. A strong understanding of normal anatomy and physiology is essential for the successful evaluation and treatment of patients with speech, language, swallowing and hearing disorders.

relationships.prereqs: Permission of instructor.

name: Anatomy, Pathology and Physiology of the Auditory System
description: Gross anatomy of the ear and pathways for transmission of sound energy through the peripheral and central auditory system. Causes, development and effects of pathological conditions contributing to temporary or chronic hearing impairments.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP202; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: Experiential Learning
description: Students will have the opportunity observe and/or participate in therapy activities provided by a speech-language pathologist or audiologist in this experiential learning course.

relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher; and permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: SIGNA Undergraduate Peer Mentor Clinical Practicum
description: Students are paired with neurodivergent UMD students to support mentoring in social communication and executive functioning skills. Peer mentors are selected based on a rigorous application process for fall and spring semesters. Selected peer mentors will engage in an orientation process which includes in depth information on neurodiversity and the intersectionality of DEI; attend a weekly lecture and group sessions to acquire up-to-date knowledge and application of knowledge with neurodiverse populations; and manage meetings with neurodivergent students one-to-one on a weekly basis to support carryover of social coaching and executive functioning strategies.

relationships.prereqs: HESP202.
relationships.restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher; and permission by instructor .
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Coursework in PSYC, EDUC, Human Development, Disability Studies.

name: SIGNA Undergraduate Peer Coach Clinical Practicum
description: Students co-lead weekly groups for neurodivergent college students, coaching on topics and strategies pertaining to social communication and executive functioning skills. Peer coaches create outlines for weekly groups which are individualized by needs and interests. Peer coaches plan monthly social outings for SIGNA personnel to support generalization of executive functioning and social communication skills. Peer coaches are selected based on a rigorous application process for fall and spring semesters. Students who previously served in a peer mentor role in SIGNA are given priority consideration as peer coaches. Peer coaches will engage in an orientation process which includes in depth information on neurodiversity; attend weekly lectures to acquire up-to-date knowledge of neurodiverse populations; and attend group debrief meetings with the course instructor on a weekly basis to support implementation of social coaching and executive functioning feedback from groups.

relationships.prereqs: HESP202.
relationships.restrictions: Junior standing or higher; and permission of instructor.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: Coursework in PSYC, EDUC, Human Development, Disability Studies, HESP396.

name: Speech and Language Development in Children
description: Analysis of the normal processes of speech and language development in children.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP300; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.additional_info: Recommended: LING200 or HESP120.

name: Language and Phonological Disorders in Children
description: Etiology, assessment and treatment of language and phonological disorders in children.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP400; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program.

name: Introduction to Phonetic Science
description: An introduction to physiological, acoustic and perceptual phonetics; broad and narrow phonetic transcription; current models of speech production and perception.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP305; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: Bases of Hearing Science
description: Fundamentals of hearing, including the physics of sound, anatomy and physiology of peripheral and central auditory nervous system, psychophysical procedures used in measurement of auditory sensation and perception, and topics in psychological acoustics.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP311; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: Introduction to Audiology
description: An introduction to the field of audiology. Evaluation and remediation of hearing handicaps.

relationships.prereqs: Minimum grade of C- in HESP311; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: Aural Rehabilitation/Habilitation
description: The fundamental aspects of aural rehabilitation therapy for both adults and children are introduced to students. Class time will consist of lectures, discussions, and hands-on activities.

relationships.prereqs: HESP411.
relationships.restrictions: Sophomore standing or higher.

name: Principles and Methods in Speech-Language Pathology
description: The principles and methods required to provide treatment of speech and language disorders to children and adults. Topics include writing goals and objectives, programming,teaching strategies,session design, data collection, behavior modification and counseling.

relationships.prereqs: HESP400.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program.

name: Principles and Methods in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology
description: The principles underlying the treatment of speech, language and hearing disorders in children and adults.

relationships.prereqs: HESP400 and HESP411; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.
relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences program; or permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: Clinical Practice in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology; Audiology Option
description: For majors only.

name: Clinical Practice in Speech-Language Pathology and Audiology; Speech Pathology Option
Global Perspectives in Communication Sciences and Disorders; International Service Learning Program
Professional Development in Research and Academia; Honors Seminar: Professional Development
Undergraduate Research Experience
description: Repeatable to 6 credits.  Undergraduate research experience working under HESP faculty or outside affiliates.

relationships.prereqs: HESP202.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department; and sophomore standing or higher.

name: Independent Study; Topics in the Hearing and Speech Sciences
Instrumentation in Hearing and Speech Sciences
description: Types and principles of operation of electronic equipment used in the hearing and speech sciences.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Clinical Audiology: Au.
relationships.additional_info: D. or Ph.D. (Doctoral) program; and permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department. Or permission of instructor.

name: Foundations of Scientific Inquiry
description: Overview of methods of empirical research used in Communication Sciences and Disorders. The course will focus on identifying, critically analyzing, and writing about empirical research.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences: M.
relationships.additional_info: Course meets over three semesters for the duration of the Masters of Speech-Language Pathology program. A. (Master's) program; or permission of Instructor.

name: Advanced Seminar in Neurological Bases of Communication
description: An advanced discussion of the neural bases of human communication and its disorders, neuroimaging, neural plasticity and neurological evaluations, with emphasis on current developments and critical analysis.

relationships.prereqs: An undergraduate course in human neuroanatomy.
relationships.restrictions: Permission of BSOS-Hearing & Speech Sciences department.

name: Seminar in Cultural and Linguistic Diversity in Communication Disorders
description: Overview of cultural and linguistic diversity (CLD) in general, and the impact of CLD on communication, communication disorders, and the professional practice of Speech-Language Pathology

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences: M.
relationships.additional_info: Course meets over four semesters for the duration of the Masters of Speech-Language Pathology program. A. (Master's) program; or permission of Instructor.

name: Assessment & Intervention in Bilingual Populations
description: Integrates foundational knowledge pertaining to bilingualism in speech-language pathology. This course provides students with a framework for working with individuals from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds. This course is designed to educate and train student clinicians to serve as bilingual speech-language pathologists.

relationships.restrictions: Must be in Hearing and Speech Sciences: M.
relationships.additional_info: A. (Master's) program.
